repnme.cdata!:
China - Second Shanghai Metropolitan
            Transport Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The assessment of outcome is
            satisfactory, sustainability highly likely, and the
            institutional development impact high. Lessons have been
            incorporated into subsequent operations, suggesting on: 1)
            road network issues: a broader road space management, and
            network planning, for had the Bank accepted the basic
            Shanghai Municipal Government's concept of a "ring
            and cross" viaduct network, working with city agencies
            towards an integrated network design, greater impacts, and a
            more effective traffic management strategy could have been
            achieved; 2) engineering design, construction, and
            procurement: that although the Bank was initially cautious
            on requiring engineering designs reviews for the ring road,
            the seemingly expertise of the Shanghai Design Institutes
            led to a participatory process, despite inexperience in
            large elevated road designs, functional design shortcomings,
            and quality of, and speediness in construction, which led to
            construction delays, and cost increases. However, the
            bidding process benefited, and stimulated the pace of reform
            of related design, and construction companies: a fair, and
            competitive construction market is emerging in Shanghai,
            under standardized competitive procurement practices; 3)
            traffic management: there is a need for institutional
            integration with traffic engineering; to complement the
            design of traffic management with traffic impact analysis;
            and, the judicious use of loan conditions could ensure the
            timely implementation of traffic management schemes; 4)
            public transport reform: that wholesale privatization of
            transport companies, is likely to be a slow process, mainly
            on the basis of unacceptable political will to
            privatization; and, 5) transport planning: that modal split
            forecasting suggests an evolution towards lower shares of
            public transport, favoring private means of transport,
            potentially leading to road congestion, and loss or productivity.

repnme.cdata!:
China - Second Shanghai Metropolitan
            Transport Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The objectives of this project are to
            enhance economic productivity by improving the operational
            and economic efficiency of the urban transport system, and
            to strengthen public sector management capacity by improving
            the planning and management of the urban transport system.
            Urban transport in Shanghai is inadequate and is starting to
            be addressed under the first Shanghai Metropolitan Transport
            Project. The project will be carried out by Shanghai
            Municipality. The Bank will provide assistance in the areas
            of strategic transport planning and multimodal transport
            systems, impact of motorization, public transport
            operations, traffic management, and transport environmental
            issues. This project is related to several key actions
            relevant to the transport sector found in the economic
            reform action plan designed to speed the evolution of the
            Shanghai economy.
